q.s: Define the concept of regime change. Identify a country studied in the AP Comparative Government and Politics course that has experienced a regime change since 1990. Explain how a change in regime is different from a change in government.
Austerity measures are implemented for the primary purpose of

o.l: addressing corruption by reducing transparency
reducing government spending to address budget deficits
improving economic conditions by increasing tariffs
increasing security in times of political instability

q.s: Identify one indicator that measures income inequality. Describe one political consequence of income inequality. Describe a policy that governments use to reduce income inequality.
Which of the following is true of environmental policies in China?

o.l: They are considered to be local issues primarily addressed at the village level.
They are difficult to implement because they often challenge or constrain economic growth.
They are mostly ineffective because of the decentralization of state power after Mao’s death.
They are nonexistent because the government does not recognize that there are any environmental problems.

q.s: Which of the following is an accurate comparison of population growth in two AP Comparative Government and Politics countries?

o.l: Russia’s government offers incentives to promote families having fewer children to alleviate problems from its rapid population growth, and Mexico continues to enforce a one-child policy to reduce population growth as a way to ensure national economic growth.

The cost of maintaining the United Kingdom’s nationalized health program increases as its older population grows proportionally larger, and China has reduced governmental restrictions on family planning in an effort to address unequal gender ratios.
Iran has had mixed policies toward population control and growth as a result of the impact of war, and the United Kingdom continues to prohibit immigration because of problems of economic growth.

Nigeria’s government has instituted a limit of two children per family to alleviate budgetary pressures from social service spending, and Mexico provides subsidies for rural residents to move to its capital city because of the capital’s low population density.

q.s: Which of the following best describes internal migration in Mexico since 2010 ?

o.l: There has been a large movement of people from urban to rural areas.
People from the south often move to the north to work in maquiladora zones.
Ethnic minority groups are given economic incentives to move to the west.
Highly skilled workers are moving to the east coast for high-tech jobs.

q.s: Which of the following best describes how members of Iran’s Guardian Council are selected?

o.l: The supreme leader directly appoints all twelve members with approval from the Assembly of Experts.
The supreme leader selects six members and the judiciary selects the other six members with Majles approval.
All twelve Guardian Council members are directly elected every four years by the electorate.
The Expediency Council appoints all twelve members of the Guardian Council every ten years.

q.s: Which of the following describes a difference between fascism and populism?

o.l: Fascism is the belief in the abolition of private property with near total governmental control over the economy, and populism is the belief in rights of the common people over elites.

Fascism is an extreme nationalist ideology that favors authoritarian rule and the rights of the ethnic majority over that of ethnic minorities, and populism is the belief in the reduction of income disparities.

Fascism is an extreme nationalist ideology that favors authoritarian rule and the rights of the ethnic majority over that of ethnic minorities, and populism is the belief in rights of the common people over elites.
Fascism is the belief in individual civil liberties and freedom over governmental restrictions, and populism is the belief in limited governmental intervention in the economy and society.

q.s: Which of the following most accurately compares the national legislatures of Iran and the United Kingdom?

o.l: In both countries, the legislatures approve legislation and oversee the budget.
In both countries, each legislature has an upper and lower house.
In both countries, laws passed by the legislatures cannot be overturned.
In both countries, there are no restrictions as to who can run for the legislature.

q.s: Which of the following statements best describes the judiciary in Russia and Nigeria?

o.l: Russian Supreme Court justices serve 4-year terms, and Nigerian Supreme Court justices serve 12-year terms.
Russian courts have the power of judicial review, but Nigerian courts do not.
Russian Supreme Court justices are approved by the president, and Nigerian Supreme Court justices are elected.
Russia’s government uses the judicial system to target opposition, and Islamic Sharia Courts have been established in northern Nigeria.

q.s: Describe the goal of sustainable development. Identify one sector of Nigeria’s economy in which sustainable development has been a serious challenge. Explain how economic factors influence environmental policy in Nigeria.
Explain one reason why both authoritarian states and democratic states use coercion domestically. Describe two ways that democratic states are constrained in their use of coercion.

Describe how the economic ideology of the Chinese Communist Party (CCP) has changed since the time Deng Xiaoping held power. Explain two reasons why the CCP has changed its economic ideology over the past 30 years.

The selection process for the chief executive helps distinguish systems that fuse powers from systems that separate powers.

(a) Describe two steps in the process of selecting the British prime minister.

(b) Explain how the selection process for the British prime minister reflects a fusion of power.

(c) Describe the process of selecting the Mexican president.

(d) Explain how the selection process for the Mexican president reflects a separation of power.

Since 2000, the Russian government has undermined civil society groups.

(a) Describe two restrictions to civil society adopted after Vladimir Putin became president in 2000.

(b) Explain why the Russian government restricts civil society.

(c) Describe one example of political activity that indicates civil society has persisted despite these restrictions.

(d) Explain why the Russian government continues to allow some civil society groups.
Which of the following accurately compares civil liberties in authoritarian and democratic regimes?

o.l: Democratic regimes provide citizens access to state-controlled media, while authoritarian regimes restrict citizen access to state-controlled media.
Authoritarian regimes limit citizen control of the media, while in democratic regimes media is largely in the hands of private citizens.
Authoritarian regimes encourage privatization of the media to increase legitimacy, while democratic regimes support some privatization along with state control.
While democratic and authoritarian regimes restrict access to free media, authoritarian regimes have increasingly allowed access to the Internet to increase legitimacy.

q.s: Which of the following is true of political systems in Mexico and Iran?

o.l: Both Iran and Mexico use a federal system to provide more local control over selecting mayors, governors, and local policy-makers.
While Mexico’s use of a federal system allows greater autonomy among the various regions, Iran’s unitary system gives greater power to the central government.
Mexico is structured as a unitary state for the purpose of unifying the 31 different regions, while Iran is structured as a federal state to reduce corruption among the 31 provinces.
Both Mexico and Iran use a unitary system as a way to reduce religious and ethnic tensions that exist in Mexico’s northern regions and in the eastern regions of Iran.

q.s: Which of the following accurately explains an outcome of differing judicial systems among the Comparative Government course countries?

o.l: The British judiciary uses common law to enforce rule of law, whereas the Russian judiciary uses the judiciary to target opposition.
The Chinese judiciary uses rule of law, whereas the Russian judiciary gets its power from judicial review.
The Nigerian judiciary is dominated by Sharia law, whereas the Mexican judiciary practices rule of law.
The Russian judiciary supports rule of law, whereas the Iranian judiciary is governed by Sharia law.

f.c:
Compare the rules for picking winners of presidential elections of two different AP Comparative Government and Politics course countries.

q.s: Describe one power of the British prime minister. Describe one way that the British parliamentary system restrains the power of the prime minister. Explain how parliamentary systems enhance the power of the prime minister in the policy-making process.
Identify an agent of political socialization. Describe the process of political socialization. Explain how political socialization affects a regime’s stability.
Define civil society. Explain one way in which civil society can strengthen democracy. Explain why democracies restrict civil society.

Describe one constitutional responsibility of the supreme leader in Iran. Describe the constitutionally defined relationship between the supreme leader and the Assembly of Experts. Describe the political relationship between the supreme leader and the Revolutionary Guard.
Explain two reasons why an authoritarian state would allow citizens to criticize the government. Describe a specific policy adopted by Russia, China, or Iran to restrict criticism of the government.

There are different types of party systems around the world.

  1. Describe one type of party system. Explain one way that type of party system influences policy making.
  2. Describe another type of party system. Explain one way that type of party system influences policy making.

  4. Explain how regime change can lead to a change in the type of party system in a country.

Elections are held in both democratic and authoritarian regimes.

The population pyramids illustrate the age and sex structure of China’s and Nigeria’s populations.

  3. Describe one economic consequence of the age structure of Nigeria.
  4. Describe one economic consequence of the age structure of China.
  5. Explain a political consequence of having a disproportionately younger population structure.
If Nigerian politicians wanted to follow the advice of this article, which of the following would be the first step to be taken?

o.l: The Nigerian Senate would vote to censure the president.
The Nigerian Supreme Court would try the president on the charge of abuse of power.
Members of the National Assembly would vote to impeach the president.
The vice president would use the authority of that office to remove the president.

q.s: Which of the following describes an accurate difference between executive term limits in Iran and in Mexico?

o.l: The Iranian president may serve unlimited terms, whereas the Mexican president is limited to one term.
The Iranian president is limited to one term, whereas the Mexican president is limited to two terms.
The Iranian president is limited to two consecutive terms, whereas the Mexican president may serve unlimited terms.
The Iranian president is limited to two terms, whereas the Mexican president is limited to one term.

q.s: Which of the following accurately describes a similarity between the parliamentary system of the United Kingdom and the presidential system of Mexico?

o.l: Both systems have separate popular elections for the chief executive and for the national legislature.
Both systems have a cabinet that advises the chief executive.
Both systems combine the lawmaking and executive functions into a single branch.
Both systems have a chief executive that serves as head of state and head of government.

q.s: In which two countries does the legislative branch have the power of impeachment?

o.l: The United Kingdom and Mexico
China and Russia
Russia and Nigeria
Iran and the United Kingdom

q.s: In comparing the legislatures of the United Kingdom and Mexico, which of the following statements is true?

o.l: In both countries, the lower house is popularly elected.
The upper house in each legislature has greater power than the lower house.
Women are more likely to be elected to the British legislature than the Mexican legislature.
Both legislatures select the head of government.

q.s: For citizens involved in legal disputes with the government in China and the United Kingdom, which of the following best explains the likely outcome?

o.l: Citizens are unlikely to receive a fair trial in both countries because both countries’ judicial systems are controlled by the ruling party.
Citizens are likely to receive a fair trial in both countries because both countries’ judicial systems hold government and citizens to the same standards.
Citizens in China are less likely to receive a fair trial because the judicial system is governed by rule by law, whereas the United Kingdom’s judicial system is governed by rule of law.

Citizens in China are more likely to receive a fair trial because Chinese courts are an important part of the Chinese government’s program to suppress corruption, while British courts have not been given the same task.

q.s: Which of the following two governments have most significantly limited citizens’ media access to maintain political control?

o.l: China and Mexico
Iran and Russia
Nigeria and the United Kingdom
Mexico and Russia

q.s: In which of the following two countries do regional cleavages play a larger role than religious cleavages do in politics?

o.l: Iran and the United Kingdom
Mexico and Iran
China and Russia
Mexico and the United Kingdom

q.s: Which of the following statements is true about the effects of cleavages in two course countries?

o.l: Regional cleavages in both Iran and the United Kingdom have resulted in groups successfully gaining independence.
Religious cleavages have led to significant separatist movements in both Nigeria and Mexico, resulting in a military response from the state.
Regional cleavages have resulted in demands for greater autonomy and independence in the United Kingdom, whereas in Mexico, regional cleavages have only resulted in demands for greater autonomy.
Ethnic cleavages have not resulted in conflict in China and Russia because the state has given fair representation in government to these groups.

q.s: Which of the following best explains the effect of the president’s combined role as both head of state and head of government in countries such as Nigeria and Mexico?

o.l: The president is responsible for both executing the laws and representing the state.
The president both acts as the chief executive and serves in the legislature, which facilitates policy making.
The president has a smaller role in foreign policy due to the combination of the roles of head of state and head of government.
The president has more independence from the demands of political parties and coalitions.

q.s: Which of the following best explains why, between general elections, the British prime minister is more likely than the president of Mexico to be replaced between general elections?

o.l: British civil society typically protests more than Mexican civil society and often demands the resignation of the prime minister.
The Mexican president can only be removed by a confidence vote, so the Mexican president tends to stay in power longer, as those votes are infrequent in Mexico.
The British government is more prone to corruption than the Mexican government, so British prime ministers are more often removed from office for criminal activity.
The British prime minister can be removed by members of Parliament (MPs), while the Mexican president can be removed only by the impeachment process.

q.s: Which of the following statements accurately describes how Mexico and Russia have responded to market forces regarding ownership of their oil and natural gas industry?

o.l: Mexico and Russia have privatized their oil and natural gas industry.
Mexico has privatized some of its oil and natural gas industry, while Russia has renationalized its oil and natural gas industry.
Mexico and Russia have recently nationalized their oil and natural gas industry.
Mexico has renationalized its oil and natural gas industry, while Russia has privatized its oil and natural gas industry.

q.s: Which of the following is the best explanation of how two AP Comparative Government and Politics course countries have responded to global market forces?

o.l: Mexico has withdrawn from the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA) to protect domestic industry, while China has privatized its economy to promote competition.
The United Kingdom has nationalized the banking industry to regulate credit markets, while Iran has allowed the Revolutionary Guard to supervise the economy to protect national interests.
China has created special economic zones (SEZs) to increase foreign direct investment, while Mexico has privatized some of its oil industry to increase competition.
The United Kingdom has nationalized natural resources to increase state revenue, while Russia has privatized natural resources to increase competition.

q.s: In which of the following pairs of countries does the government exercise significant state control of the media?

o.l: Russia and Nigeria
Iran and Mexico
China and Russia
United Kingdom and Nigeria

q.s: Which of the following best demonstrates that a country has transitioned from an authoritarian government to a democratic government?

o.l: Elected officials are better able to influence judicial rulings.
Multiple political parties join to form a single dominant political party.
The chief executive has greater authority than the legislature.
Elections for public office are more transparent and competitive.

q.s: Which of the following statements accurately describes the military in both China and Iran?

o.l: The military was responsible for the establishment of the current regime.
The military is apolitical and does not engage in political activities.
The military is under the direct control of the president as commander-in-chief.
The military has been used to suppress public demonstrations.

q.s: Rule of law is stronger in the United Kingdom than it is in Russia because

o.l: common law in the United Kingdom establishes judicial review, whereas the Constitution in Russia does not
the United Kingdom is a parliamentary system, whereas Russia is a semi-presidential system
the United Kingdom has a Supreme Court, whereas Russia does not
the judiciary in the United Kingdom is independent, whereas the judiciary in Russia is not

presidential systems
democratic systems
unicameral systems

q.s: The power of the Russian prime minister is more limited than the power of the prime minister in the United Kingdom because

o.l: only in the United Kingdom does the prime minister act as head of government
the Russian prime minister is limited by a much more powerful head of state
the parliament in the United Kingdom has the power to pass laws, whereas the Russian parliament does not
the United Kingdom has an unwritten constitution, whereas Russia has a written constitution

q.s: Which two countries use both first-past-the-post and proportional representation systems in elections to the lower house of the legislature?

o.l: Mexico and Nigeria
Mexico and Russia
Nigeria and Russia

q.s: Which of the following accurately compares social movements in AP Comparative Government and Politics course countries?

o.l: In Nigeria, the Movement for the Emancipation of the Niger Delta (MEND) protested unjust methods of extraction and distribution of oil, while Iran’s Green Movement protested electoral corruption.
Both Iran’s Green Movement and Mexico’s Zapatista movement primarily responded to socioeconomic inequality.
Mexico’s Zapatista movement primarily advocated for free and fair elections, while Nigeria’s Movement for the Survival of the Ogoni People (MOSOP) favored the establishment of an Islamic state.
Iran’s Green Movement primarily favored separatism, while Nigeria’s Boko Haram advocates for Shari‘a law.

q.s: Which of the following best explains a characteristic of elections in Mexico and Nigeria?

o.l: Mexico and Nigeria both have thresholds for parties to win seats in the legislature, which have reduced the number of parties that win seats.
Mexico and Nigeria both have rules that require the president to earn a minimum percentage of votes in each state, which has reduced the impact of regional differences upon electoral results.
Mexico and Nigeria both have single-member district (SMD) electoral systems, which increases the number of parties in the legislature.
Mexico and Nigeria both have independent electoral commissions to reduce the impact of corrupt practices upon election results.

q.s: Which of the following issues from the past ten years have led to significant public protests in Russia?

o.l: The firing of Prime Minister Medvedev by President Putin
The nationalization of the oil industry by the government
The election fraud and corruption of the government
The privatization of state-run media

q.s: Which of the following best describes democratic consolidation?

o.l: When a political party is able to control both the legislative branch and executive branch, thereby consolidating its power
When a democratic regime matures in its protections of civil rights and liberties and is thereby unlikely to revert to an authoritarian regime
When a president is popularly elected by a majority of the population, thereby establishing a mandate
When multiparty system gives way to a two-party system, thereby consolidating the number of political parties

q.s: When a government shares information about policy making with citizens to ensure accountability, this is referred to as

o.l: democratization
political socialization
regime stability

q.s: The main duty of China’s Standing Committee of the National People’s Congress (NPC) is to

operate as the center of power in the Chinese state

q.s: The primary difference between a commander in chief in a democratic regime and a commander in chief in an authoritarian regime is that only in

o.l: an authoritarian regime is the commander in chief in charge of the military
a democratic regime is the commander in chief accountable to the citizens
an authoritarian regime can the commander in chief use the military to enforce domestic law
a democratic regime can the commander in chief be removed

q.s: Which of the following explains why a country would choose a parliamentary system over a presidential system?

o.l: A parliamentary system fuses its branches of government, which increases citizen participation since there are more elected offices.
A parliamentary system divides governmental power between a central power and regional governments, so policy making is more effective.
A parliamentary system allows citizens to directly elect its head of government, so it offers more accountability.
A parliamentary system does not divide powers among as many branches of government, so it is more efficient.

q.s: An interest group system that controls access to policy making by relying on state-sanctioned groups to represent labor, business, and agricultural sectors is

o.l: socialist
corporatist
populist
pluralist

q.s: Which of the following accurately compares interest groups and social movements?

o.l: Interest groups are organized to advocate for a specific policy issue, whereas social movements advocate for broad social change.
Interest groups only function in a pluralist system, whereas social movements only function in a corporatist system.
Interest groups are more effective in an authoritarian state, whereas social movements are more effective in a democratic state.
Interest groups have more access to the policy-making process in a unitary state, whereas social movements have more access in a federal system.

q.s: Which of the following is a consequence of one-party rule in China?

o.l: Minor parties have formed coalitions to challenge the dominance of the Chinese Communist Party (CCP).
Corporations have fought to change restrictive regulations imposed by the CCP.
Minor parties have limited influence on policy making in China.

q.s: Which of the following would most likely increase legitimacy in Iran?

o.l: A disputed transfer of power
Jailing of religious leaders
Selection of a less charismatic leader
Economic growth

q.s: Which of the following statements accurately describes a cleavage in Iran?

The coalition of Azerbaijanis and Kurds is an ethnic cleavage that threatens the stability of Iran’s regime.

q.s: Which of the following best describes the role of civil society organizations in the AP Comparative Government and Politics course countries?

o.l: Civil society organizations are mostly free of government interference.
Civil society organizations resist involvement in international issues.
Civil society organizations are focused on reducing government regulations.

q.s: Which of the following describes a policy employed by the Chinese government to establish legitimacy with ethnic minorities?

o.l: Use of military force to suppress popular uprisings
Creation of special economic zones (SEZs) to reduce inequality

q.s: Which of the following accurately compares political culture and political ideology?

o.l: Political culture is composed of a set of broadly shared attitudes and values, whereas political ideology is a more specific set of beliefs or values about government and politics.
Political ideology can be transmitted by the process of political socialization, but political culture cannot.
Political culture frames policy choices made by governments, but political ideology influences only individual decisions about elections.

q.s: Political diversity in Iran’s Majles is most constrained by which of the following?

o.l: The vetting of candidates by the Guardian Council
The unwillingness of Iranians to support candidates who would challenge the government
The use of a single-member district (SMD) electoral system in Iran
The dominance of a single party in the Majiles

q.s: Why do single-member district (SMD) electoral systems tend to promote two-party systems?

o.l: Parties in a SMD electoral system have to build coalitions after elections to form a government, and these coalitions often develop into larger parties.
SMD electoral systems always require runoff elections, which discriminate against minor parties.
Only one candidate can win in a SMD electoral system, so minor parties are less likely to win.
A representative in a SMD electoral system is more accountable to voters, so representatives need larger parties to support their constituency service efforts.

q.s: Which of these countries has had a dominant-party system since 2000 ?

o.l: Iran
China
Mexico
Russia

q.s: Which of the following actions would a government take as part of an economic liberalization program?

o.l: Increasing tariffs
Redistributing wealth
Strengthening regulations on the private sector

q.s: Austerity measures are usually adopted by countries that are seeking to

o.l: control rapid growth of the economy
reduce dependence on imported fossil fuels
lower budget deficits and publicly held debt
expand social welfare policies that address poverty

q.s: Which of the following best compares import substitution policies and neoliberal economic policies?

o.l: The goal of import substitution policies is to protect domestic industries, whereas neoliberal policies seek to decrease reliance on foreign direct investment (FDI).
Import substitution policies are usually adopted by countries with developed economies, whereas neoliberal policies are adopted by countries with high levels of inequality.
Import substitution policies support reducing deficits, whereas neoliberal policies support raising taxes.
Import substitution policies include increasing tariffs, whereas neoliberal policies encourage lower tariffs.

q.s: Which of the following is the best explanation of how natural resources have affected political development in Nigeria?

o.l: Oil extraction in Nigeria has allowed the government to diversify its economy.
Oil extraction in Nigeria has allowed the government to redistribute funds to citizens, limiting economic inequality and promoting democracy.
Oil extraction in Nigeria has motivated political elites to seek government control of these resources, deepening corruption and impeding democratic consolidation.
Oil extraction in Nigeria has helped the economy and allowed the government to focus on increasing transparency.

q.s: Which of the following best explains a demographic consequence of economic policies in Mexico?

o.l: Economic liberalization policies influenced job creation in northern Mexico, prompting migration from the south to the north.
Economic liberalization policies failed in northern Mexico, prompting migration to southern Mexico.
Economic liberalization policies influenced job creation in rural areas of Mexico, prompting the growth of major cities throughout the country.
Economic liberalization policies were successful in southern Mexico, prompting population growth there.

q.s: Which of the following policies to limit population growth is more likely to be adopted by authoritarian regimes than by democratic regimes?

o.l: Restricting access to birth control
Restricting family size
Providing education about family planning
Providing health care for all citizens

q.s: Which of the following policies would a government be likely to undertake to address gender equity in a political system?

o.l: Limiting access to family planning and education
Implementing gender equity wage policies and reducing taxes
Increasing access to family planning and limiting access to education
Implementing gender quotas in legislative elections and improving access to education

q.s: Which of the following correctly describes the relationship between the Mexican Supreme Court of Justice and other political institutions in Mexico?

o.l: The president has the constitutional power to overrule decisions made by the National Supreme Court of Justice.
The president has the power to appoint or nominate members to the National Supreme Court of Justice.
Mexico’s constitution does not provide for an independent judiciary.

q.s: Which of the following assertions is used by the author to support the claim in the passage?

o.l: López Obrador is attempting to eliminate the judicial system.
López Obrador is attempting to control judicial decision making.
López Obrador is moving to establish more constitutional checks on the judiciary.
López Obrador intends to protect the power of the Senate to approve Supreme Court magistrates.

f.c:
Latin America’s two biggest economies are in their first 100 days under new management. During the presidential campaigns in Brazil and Mexico, democracy’s champions worried most about Brazil, given Jair Bolsonaro’s nostalgia for military rule. Yet today it is Mexico’s democracy that is under greater threat: President Andrés Manuel López Obrador, known as AMLO, is systematically concentrating power in an already strong executive.

From the start, AMLO has undermined democratic norms and checks and balances. Despite controlling a constitutional majority in Mexico’s Chamber of Deputies and sizable majority in its Senate, he has often chosen to work outside the formal legislative process. Instead he has relied on dubious public “referendums,” sampling small and politically skewed groups to set agricultural policy, boost pensions, authorize infrastructure projects and create scholarships.

He has attacked and stacked the courts. He quickly moved to cut judges’ salaries and take control of court officials’ evaluations and promotions. His first nominations to the highest bench include the wife of a favored contractor and party loyalists.

Source: Shannon K. O’Neil, “López Obrador is Dismantling Democracy in Mexico,” Bloomberg Opinion, March 11, 2019

q.s: López Obrador’s actions best reflect which of the following ideologies?

o.l: Individualism, because of López Obrador’s interactions with the courts.
Neoliberalism, because of López Obrador’s authorization of infrastructure projects.
Communism, because of López Obrador’s agricultural policies.
Populism, because of López Obrador’s use of referenda.

f.c:
Latin America’s two biggest economies are in their first 100 days under new management. During the presidential campaigns in Brazil and Mexico, democracy’s champions worried most about Brazil, given Jair Bolsonaro’s nostalgia for military rule. Yet today it is Mexico’s democracy that is under greater threat: President Andrés Manuel López Obrador, known as AMLO, is systematically concentrating power in an already strong executive.

From the start, AMLO has undermined democratic norms and checks and balances. Despite controlling a constitutional majority in Mexico’s Chamber of Deputies and sizable majority in its Senate, he has often chosen to work outside the formal legislative process. Instead he has relied on dubious public “referendums,” sampling small and politically skewed groups to set agricultural policy, boost pensions, authorize infrastructure projects and create scholarships.

He has attacked and stacked the courts. He quickly moved to cut judges’ salaries and take control of court officials’ evaluations and promotions. His first nominations to the highest bench include the wife of a favored contractor and party loyalists.

Source: Shannon K. O’Neil, “López Obrador is Dismantling Democracy in Mexico,” Bloomberg Opinion, March 11, 2019

q.s: Which of the following best describes the author’s claim in the passage?

o.l: The author argues that preexisting inequalities negatively affect civil society during democratization.
The author argues that civil society systematically strengthens in democratizing countries.
The author argues that reversals of democracy are primarily due to the impact of globalization.
The author argues that democratization allows the poor to organize and gain access to the political system.

f.c:
Civil society organizations and broad movements of protest can facilitate collective action by popular groups of the poor and disenfranchised endowing them with a greater capacity to shape institutions and policy agendas. . . . With the growth of inequality in many countries . . . conditions for the empowerment of and civic action by popular groups are much less [positive]. . . . [T]he material insecurity provoked by deindustrialization and labor market deregulation have contributed to the loss of the material and organizational resources essential for collective action. . . .” Some argue, “that growing inequalities not only “inevitably install large resource disparities in the political arena,” they also “inhibit coalition formation. . . .”

[T]hese conditions have had a particularly profound impact in the democracies that have emerged since the 1970s, most of which inherited highly inegalitarian social and political structures caused by prolonged periods of authoritarianism. In many new democratizing settings . . . globalization and austerity policies reinforced inherited patterns of inequality. . . . Thus, socioeconomic inequality itself makes it harder for the poor to organize and contest the growth of inequality. This trap affects many new democracies and, at its root, is caused by the fact that they have, on average, weaker civil societies compared to older, established democracies.

Source: “Civil Society and Democracy in an Era of Inequality,” Comparative Politics (April 2017), pp. 391-409

q.s: Which of the following recommendations would the author most likely agree with in regard to democratic transitions?

o.l: Domestic economic and international development policies that do not address economic inequality will negatively affect the emergence of civil society groups.
Policy makers in new democracies should continue to focus on deindustrialization and labor market deregulation, which will positively affect the emergence of civil society groups.
International development actors such as the International Monetary Fund (IMF) should continue to support economic liberalization, which will positively affect the emergence of civil society groups.
New democracies should work to globalize their economies, which will positively affect economic growth and the emergence of civil society groups.

f.c:
Civil society organizations and broad movements of protest can facilitate collective action by popular groups of the poor and disenfranchised endowing them with a greater capacity to shape institutions and policy agendas. . . . With the growth of inequality in many countries . . . conditions for the empowerment of and civic action by popular groups are much less [positive]. . . . [T]he material insecurity provoked by deindustrialization and labor market deregulation have contributed to the loss of the material and organizational resources essential for collective action. . . .” Some argue, “that growing inequalities not only “inevitably install large resource disparities in the political arena,” they also “inhibit coalition formation. . . .”

[T]hese conditions have had a particularly profound impact in the democracies that have emerged since the 1970s, most of which inherited highly inegalitarian social and political structures caused by prolonged periods of authoritarianism. In many new democratizing settings . . . globalization and austerity policies reinforced inherited patterns of inequality. . . . Thus, socioeconomic inequality itself makes it harder for the poor to organize and contest the growth of inequality. This trap affects many new democracies and, at its root, is caused by the fact that they have, on average, weaker civil societies compared to older, established democracies.

Source: “Civil Society and Democracy in an Era of Inequality,” Comparative Politics (April 2017), pp. 391-409

q.s:
Develop an argument as to whether a country should or should not join a supranational organization.

Use one or more of the following course concepts in your response.

  • Sovereignty
  • Globalization
  • Economic liberalization

f.c:
In your response you should do the following.

✓ Respond to the prompt with a defensible claim or thesis that establishes a line of reasoning using one or more of the provided course concepts.

✓ Support your claim with at least TWO pieces of specific and relevant evidence from one or more course countries. The evidence should be relevant to one or more of the provided course concepts.

✓ Use reasoning to explain why your evidence supports your claim or thesis, using one or more provided course concepts.

✓ Respond to an opposing or alternate perspective using refutation, concession, or rebuttal.

Globalization usually results in regime instability caused by international pressures for democratization.

Inequality between rich and poor makes them susceptible to social conflict.

o.l: Being nominated and appointed through political party lists
Being elected by members of the House of Commons
Winning a seat through a national election

q.s: Which of the following best describes an effect of recent demographic change in the United Kingdom?

o.l: Recent shortfalls of natural resources have resulted in a negative net migration.
The government has created special economic zones to encourage immigration.
A positive net migration of immigrants that has resulted in social and political tensions.

q.s: Which of the following institutions most limit the exercise of independent legislative power?

o.l: Mexico’s National Electoral Institute (INE) and Nigeria’s Independent National Electoral Commission (INEC)
China’s Standing Committee of the Politburo and Iran’s Guardian Council
United Kingdom’s House of Lords and Nigeria’s president
Iran’s Supreme Leader and the United Kingdom’s monarchy

q.s: Which of the following pairs of countries both require that the chief executive receive an absolute majority of the public’s votes to be elected?

o.l: Iran and Russia
Iran and Mexico
Nigeria and the United Kingdom
Mexico and Nigeria

q.s: Which of the following best explains why both Nigeria and the United Kingdom have two major political parties?

o.l: Both countries’ politics focus on economic issues, which leads to one party representing business interests while the other party represents labor interests.
Both countries’ electoral systems use single-member districts with first-past-the-post rules, which tend to favor catch-all parties.
Nigeria’s main cleavage is ethnic, while the United Kingdom’s main cleavage is regional, favoring two parties that represent those ethnic and regional cleavages.
Nigeria’s corrupt electoral authority suppresses small parties, while the United Kingdom’s use of proportional representation underrepresents small parties.

q.s: Which of the following best explains why the policy-making process in the United Kingdom is usually more efficient than in Mexico?

o.l: The separation of the roles of head of state and head of government in the United Kingdom, unlike the combination of the roles in Mexico, creates fewer institutional obstacles to enacting policy.
The presence of two significant political parties in the United Kingdom, rather than three as in Mexico, creates fewer political obstacles to enacting policy.
The presence of a greater number of significant social cleavages in Mexico than in the United Kingdom makes it difficult to achieve policy-making consensus.
The fusion of executive and legislative power in the United Kingdom leads to fewer institutional obstacles to enacting policy, whereas the divided branch powers in Mexico make it more difficult.

q.s: Which of the following best describes the authors’ evidence that Supreme Leader Khamenei sided with President Ahmadinejad in the aftermath of the 2009 presidential election in Iran?

o.l: Khamenei changed the role of president to take a more active role in politics.
Khamenei used the Revolutionary Guard to preserve the status quo by suppressing protests.
Khamenei altered the results of the election to favor Ahmadinejad.
Khamenei formed the Green Movement to counter protests by opponents of the regime.

f.c:
The 2009 presidential election in the Islamic Republic of Iran was one of the most transformative events in Iran’s modern history. It bared important schisms within the .·.·. political system and pitted two key camps against one another, each with a very different vision of what Iran should be and what it should become. It appeared to solidify . . . under President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad and continued an ongoing militarization of Iranian politics led by the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps. . . . The widespread fraud alleged by the leading opposition candidate, former Prime Minister Mir Hossein Mousavi, and the .·.·. (political system’s) repressive response irrevocably shattered an unspoken contract between the government and the people—one in which the theocratic government had allowed some popular political participation and limited personal space in return for the people’s acquiescence to the status quo.

Even the highest authority in Iran, the Supreme Leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, did not escape censure by the opposition—a traditional “red line” in Iranian politics that clerics, politicians, and voters alike crossed numerous times after the polls closed. Previously, Khamenei had portrayed himself as above the often-brutal factional “fray” in Iran. But now he came down decisively on the side of Ahmadinejad and his hard-line allies and used the Revolutionary Guard to preserve the status quo. In so doing, he altered the role of the office he occupied.

Source: Alireza Nader, David E. Thaler, and S.R. Bohand. The Next Supreme Leader: Succession in the Islamic Republic of Iran. Rand National Defense Research Institute, 2011

Head of government
Commander in chief
Chief justice of Iran

o.l: The regime’s legitimacy will weaken because of the supreme leader’s change from his traditionally neutral role in politics.
The regime’s legitimacy will weaken because of disapproval of the regime’s electoral practices by the global community.
The regime’s legitimacy will strengthen because of the regime’s repression of dissent against Ahmadinejad.
The regime’s legitimacy will strengthen because of Iranians’ fear that the Revolutionary Guards will harshly repress any protest.

f.c:
The 2009 presidential election in the Islamic Republic of Iran was one of the most transformative events in Iran’s modern history. q.s: Which of the following best explains why the Chinese government allows some political protests?

o.l: To promote democratization among citizens
To open political discourse
To spread political information
To act as a release valve for the public

q.s: Which of the following best explains a consequence of the way power is distributed in a unitary system?

o.l: Because power is diffused among several levels of government, responses to the needs of citizens are slower and often contradictory.
Because power is shared equally between a national government and subnational governments, public policy is static and cannot change over time.
Because power is concentrated in the national government with some distribution to subnational levels, policy making is often efficient.
Because power is centralized in one place, the national government makes all decisions and there are no other levels of governments.

q.s: Which of the following is an accurate explanation of state sovereignty?

o.l: A state is sovereign when it makes independent, binding decisions for its population and territory.
A state is sovereign when it relies on other states to protect its borders.
A state is sovereign when it is forced to abide by decisions made by another state.
A state is sovereign when the international community does not recognize it.

q.s: Which of the following is an accurate comparison of a head of state and a head of government?

o.l: A head of government generally serves as the leader in charge of conducting foreign policy, while a head of state serves as the leader with sole responsibility for executing domestic policy.

A head of state serves as the chief executive responsible for enforcing laws and treaties, while a head of government serves as the leader of the legislature with sole responsibility for creating policy.
A head of government generally serves as the symbolic political representative, while a head of state is the official responsible for running the government.
A head of state generally serves as the symbolic political representative of the nation, while a head of government is the official responsible for running the government.

q.s: Which of the following is an accurate explanation of an advantage of executive term limits?

o.l: Executive term limits allow legislators to develop coherent policies over time.
Executive term limits allow executives greater control over the legislative process.
Executive term limits can prevent executives from consolidating power.
Executive term limits can weaken accountability.

q.s: Which of the following is a correct explanation of the limited power of the Iranian Majles?

o.l: The power of the Majles is limited because the Iranian Constitution created a theocratic state with democratic characteristics, with religious leaders having more power in the system.
The power of the Majles is limited because only the Supreme Leader can ensure that legislation is compatible with Islamic law.
The power of the Majles is limited because Iran is a federal system and state legislatures have an important voice in national policy.
The power of the Majles is limited because the Iranian Constitution gives the Expediency Council the power to approve candidates for elective office.

q.s: Which of the following best explains the impact of electoral rules on the number of effective political parties in the legislatures in Russia and the United Kingdom?

o.l: In Russia, electoral rules have resulted in competitive parties and a multiparty legislature, while in the United Kingdom, electoral rules have allowed regional parties to win a majority of seats in the legislature.

In Russia, electoral rules have made it difficult for parties to compete or gain representation in the legislature, while in the United Kingdom, single-member districts have resulted in a legislature with only two parties.
In Russia, single-member districts have resulted in a two-party dominant system, while in the United Kingdom, electoral rules limit minor parties and have resulted in a single-party dominant system.

In Russia, electoral rules have limited the number of parties in the legislature, while in the United Kingdom, electoral rules have allowed regional parties to win legislative seats while maintaining a system with two major parties.

q.s: Which of the following is an accurate comparison of the current political party systems in Russia and China?

o.l: China has a two-party system, while Russia has a dominant-party system.
China has a one-party system, while Russia has a dominant-party system.
China has a multiparty system, while Russia has a one-party system.
China has a dominant-party system, while Russia has a one-party system.

q.s: Which of the following accurately explains a consequence of economic liberalization policies in China?

o.l: Economic liberalization in China created job growth on the east coast, causing migration from the west to the east.
Economic liberalization in China created job growth in urban areas, driving migration from the east to the west.
Economic liberalization in China created job growth in rural areas, driving migration from the cities to the countryside.
Economic liberalization in China created job growth in the north, driving migration from the south to the north.

q.s: Which of the following is an accurate comparison of sources of legitimacy in Iran and Mexico?

o.l: In Iran, the regime primarily derives its legitimacy from the Assembly of Experts, while in Mexico, the primary source of legitimacy is the rule of law.
In Iran, the regime primarily derives its legitimacy from the rule of law, while in Mexico, the primary source of legitimacy is the Supreme Court.
In Iran, the regime primarily derives its legitimacy from the Supreme Leader, while in Mexico, the primary source of legitimacy is the president.
In Iran, the regime primarily derives its legitimacy from religion, while in Mexico, the primary source of legitimacy is the constitution.

q.s: Which of the following is an accurate explanation of the difference between political party systems in Iran and the United Kingdom?

o.l: The political party system in Iran reflects the principles of Islamic law, while in the United Kingdom, the political party system is corporatist.

The political party system in Iran has evolved to a single-party dominant system, while in the United Kingdom, political parties have clear platforms and membership rules and compete effectively in elections.

Political parties in Iran are unable to effectively support candidates for election and are not well-established, while in the United Kingdom, political parties are free to compete and the election rules in place have resulted in a system with two major parties.

Political parties in Iran have been unable to raise funds necessary to sustain themselves, leading to a collapse in the party system, while in the United Kingdom, political parties are free to compete and raise money for elections, which has resulted in a two-party dominant system.

q.s: Which of the following best describes a pluralist interest-group system’s policy-making process?

o.l: Competition among autonomous groups
Equal representation of key economic sectors
Government-controlled accessibility to policy makers
Representation of multiple parties in the legislature

q.s: Which of the following best describes pluralist systems?

o.l: They support economic policies that are developed and run by the state.
They allow the state to maintain control over citizen input and participation.
They promote competition among autonomous groups not linked to the state.
They use single peak associations to represent the business sector.

q.s: An illiberal democracy is also known as which of the following?

o.l: A competitive authoritarian regime
A substantive democracy
A corporatist democracy
A democratic socialist regime

q.s: Which of the following accurately describes the Chinese government’s imposition of restrictions on civil society groups?

o.l: The government is transparent in the regulations that it applies to civil society groups.
The government’s actions contradict guarantees of civil liberties in its constitution.
The government restricts groups protesting living standards more than it restricts those opposing party rule.
The government faces severe repercussions from the international community.

q.s: Which of the following is the purpose of the Great Firewall in China?

o.l: To expand infrastructure to rural areas in the west
To facilitate migration from rural to urban areas
To increase global influence through cross-border road projects
To limit political criticism on social media

q.s: Which of the following statements best compares government regulation of civil society in Russia with that of the United Kingdom?

o.l: Only in Russia must civil society groups register with the government.
Only in Russia does the government provide all funding for civil society groups.
The Russian government monitors civil society groups much more closely than does the government of the United Kingdom.
In both Russia and the United Kingdom the government frequently jails members of opposition civil society groups.

q.s: Which of the following is a consequence of the bicameral legislature in both Mexico and the United Kingdom?

o.l: Subnational governments are protected because the upper chamber must approve federal intervention in state matters.
Civilian control of the military is assured because the upper chamber must approve troop deployment.
There is a check on the executive because there is fusion of power between the two chambers.
Policy making is slowed because both chambers participate in the policy-making process.

q.s: Which of the following is true of the cabinet in both Mexico and Nigeria?

o.l: The courts must review all cabinet member nominations by the executive.
The legislature must approve cabinet members nominated by the executive.
Cabinet members must be members of the legislature.
The cabinet is solely accountable to the executive branch.

q.s: Which of the following best describes both China and Iran?

o.l: Both have a unitary system of government.
Both have a one-party system.
Both have a bicameral legislature.
Both have a semi-presidential system of government.

q.s: Which of the following best describes the main point of the passage?

o.l: China has aggressively pursued a singular economic approach in its relations with Africa.
Economic relations with Africa have involved the Chinese government, not Chinese private sector actors.
Development loans to African nations represent a decreasing share of Chinese revenue sources.
The scale of borrowing by African countries increases the likelihood of future debt problems.

f.c:
China has taken a multi-pronged approach in its economic relations with Africa, according to Deborah Brautigam [of] Johns Hopkins School of Advanced and International Studies. China is a significant source of  foreign direct investment in Africa; offers development loans to resource-rich nations . . . invests in agriculture; and develops special trade and economic cooperation zones in several states . . . “Chinese banks and companies are offering finance that allows them to secure a greater share of the business deals in Africa as part of their move to ‘go global.’ This brings with it risks for African borrowers—but also opportunities,” writes Brautigam.

Chinese financing comes often in the form of loans and credits provided by the People’s Bank of China, the China Development Bank, the Export-Import Bank of China, and the China-Africa Development Fund. Between 2000 and 2014, Chinese banks, contractors, and the government loaned more than $86 billion to Africa . . . However, these large loans are beginning to raise questions about debt loads in African countries, showing indications of a potential debt crisis.

Council on Foreign Relations, 2019

q.s: According to the passage, which of the following is the most likely implication of China’s current economic policies toward African nations?

o.l: African nations may adopt Communist principles to continue to attract Chinese aid.
Indebted African nations may lose sovereignty to the Chinese government and large banks.
China may become a member of regional African economic organizations such as ECOWAS.
China’s economic growth may become overly dependent on resources from Africa.

f.c:
China has taken a multi-pronged approach in its economic relations with Africa, according to Deborah Brautigam [of] Johns Hopkins School of Advanced and International Studies. China is a significant source of  foreign direct investment in Africa; offers development loans to resource-rich nations . . . invests in agriculture; and develops special trade and economic cooperation zones in several states . . . “Chinese banks and companies are offering finance that allows them to secure a greater share of the business deals in Africa as part of their move to ‘go global.’ This brings with it risks for African borrowers—but also opportunities,” writes Brautigam.

Chinese financing comes often in the form of loans and credits provided by the People’s Bank of China, the China Development Bank, the Export-Import Bank of China, and the China-Africa Development Fund. Between 2000 and 2014, Chinese banks, contractors, and the government loaned more than $86 billion to Africa . . . However, these large loans are beginning to raise questions about debt loads in African countries, showing indications of a potential debt crisis.

Council on Foreign Relations, 2019

q.s: Which of the following is an accurate description of the Mexican judiciary?

o.l: There is no functioning Supreme Court in Mexico.
Mexico's judiciary does not have the power of judicial review.
Supreme Court justices are appointed by the president and confirmed by the Senate.
Supreme Court justices are appointed to a life term.

q.s: Which of the following best explains how power in the National People’s Congress is constrained?

o.l: China’s upper house is required to approve all legislation passed by the National People’s Congress concerning the annual budget.
The National People’s Congress is directly elected by the people, so representatives must take constituents’ needs into consideration when passing legislation.
The National People’s Congress is subservient to the Politburo Standing Committee, which is the actual center of power in China.
The National People’s Congress is recognized by the constitution as the most powerful institution of government and has no constraints.

o.l: The Gini index
The Human Development Index (HDI)
Gross domestic product (GDP)
Freedom House

q.s: Which of the following statements did most poll respondents say described the state of political affairs in Nigeria?

o.l: Elected officials care what ordinary people think.
No matter who wins an election, things do not change very much.
The court systems treat everyone fairly.
Most politicians are corrupt.

q.s: Which of the following best explains why many respondents to the poll agreed that the statement “The court system treats everyone fairly” described Nigeria well?

o.l: The Nigerian government has eliminated the Shariah Courts in the north.
The Nigerian government has arrested and issued lengthy sentences to political protesters.
The president has been significantly increasing the size of the Nigerian court system and has appointed judges who support the same political ideology.
The Nigerian government has made an effort to reduce corruption in the judicial system by protecting the power of judicial review and independence.

q.s: Which of the following is an implication of the chart?

o.l: The Nigerian independent election commission will continue to fail to reduce voter fraud in elections.
Civil society does not exist in Nigeria to challenge corrupt politicians.
Nigerian citizens are critical of Nigerian politicians and have low levels of political trust.
The courts are ineffective in addressing the needs of Islamic citizens in the north.

q.s: Which of the following best explains an important step in the democratic consolidation process?

o.l: Removing civil liberties from any group that protests against the government helps to maintain order.
Establishing rule by law means government officials are treated like everyone else.
Reducing public access to government documents allows for greater efficiency in decision making.
Allowing for competitive and fair elections gives citizens the right to express their political opinions.

q.s: Which of the following is a check on the executive in both a presidential and a parliamentary system?

o.l: There may be imposed time deadlines on calling new elections.
The lower house of the legislature may pass an impeachment resolution.
The legislature may refuse to pass executive proposed legislation.
The Supreme Court may remove the executive from office.

q.s: Which of the following best describes the difference between fascism and communism?

o.l: Fascism is the belief in the interests and rights of the common people over that of the elites, and communism is the belief in the nationalization of all industries.
Fascism is the belief in a nationalist ideology favoring authoritarian rule, and communism is the belief in the removal of private property and government control over the economy.
Fascism is the belief in the reduction of income disparities among all people, and communism is the belief in individual civil liberties and freedoms over government intrusion or restriction.
Fascism is the belief in limited government intervention in the economy and society, and communism is the belief in the deregulation of trade and the elimination of subsidies.

q.s: Which of the following explains the effect the Guardian Council’s powers have on presidential candidates in Iran?

o.l: The Guardian Council only allows the two major political parties to run presidential candidates thus limiting the ability of a minor party candidate being elected president.
The Guardian Council excludes nonclerics limiting the number of candidates that are eligible to run for president.
The Guardian Council appoints the president making it important that presidential candidates are loyal to the Guardian Council.
The Guardian Council restricts the number of reform-minded presidential candidates limiting the number of candidates.

q.s: Which of the following is a reason why a country might implement import substitution industrialization (ISI) policies?

o.l: The country is attempting to attract more private capital and foreign direct investment.
The country is attempting to lower tariffs and improve its economy.
The country is attempting to reduce foreign influence on its economy.
The country is attempting to create more state-owned companies.

q.s: According to the author, which of the following economic policies is most likely to successfully address the problems discussed in the passage?

o.l: Social welfare
Austerity
Neoliberalism
Trade liberalization

f.c:
Civil society organizations and broad movements of protest can facilitate collective action by popular groups of the poor and disenfranchised endowing them with a greater capacity to shape institutions and policy agendas. . . . With the growth of inequality in many countries . . . conditions for the empowerment of and civic action by popular groups are much less [positive]. . . . [T]he material insecurity provoked by deindustrialization and labor market deregulation have contributed to the loss of the material and organizational resources essential for collective action. . . .” Some argue, “that growing inequalities not only “inevitably install large resource disparities in the political arena,” they also “inhibit coalition formation. . . .”

[T]hese conditions have had a particularly profound impact in the democracies that have emerged since the 1970s, most of which inherited highly inegalitarian social and political structures caused by prolonged periods of authoritarianism. In many new democratizing settings . . . globalization and austerity policies reinforced inherited patterns of inequality. . . . Thus, socioeconomic inequality itself makes it harder for the poor to organize and contest the growth of inequality. This trap affects many new democracies and, at its root, is caused by the fact that they have, on average, weaker civil societies compared to older, established democracies.

Source: “Civil Society and Democracy in an Era of Inequality,” Comparative Politics (April 2017), pp. 391-409

q.s: Which of the following statements about females with primary school education in 1986 and 2016 is true?

o.l: In China, less than 45 percent of females had a primary school education in 2016.
In Russia, more than 49 percent of females had a primary school education in 2016.
In Nigeria, 48 percent of females had a primary school education in 1986.
In Iran, more than 49 percent of females had a primary school education in 1986.

f.c: Source: World Bank, 2016.

q.s: Which of the following best explains the reason for Iran’s change in percentage of females with primary school education between 1986 and 2016 ?

o.l: After the revolution, the Iranian government stopped females from attending primary school and secondary school.
Hardliners in the 1990s refused to allow females the right to attend school or sporting events.
The supreme leader changed national laws to allow women the right to vote and receive secondary education.
The Iranian government created education policies that encouraged females to attend primary school.

f.c: Source: World Bank, 2016.
